news_item.abstract: The orchestra tackled a premiere by Brendan Faegre and Mahler’s marathon “Resurrection” Symphony.

news_item.title: Zoo Director Responds to Gorilla Death
news_item.abstract: The director of the Cincinnati Zoo addressed the killing of a silverback gorilla Harambe, saying the shooting was justified because the child who fell into the animal's pen was in serious danger.

link.suggested_link_text: Gorilla Killed After Child Enters Enclosure at Cincinnati Zoo

news_item.title: Triplet and Higher-Order Births in U.S. Down 41%
news_item.abstract: The decline, which comes after a rapid rise in the 1980s and ’90s, occurred between 1998 and 2014, according to a new report.

link.suggested_link_text: With In Vitro Fertilization, Persistence Pays Off, Study Suggests

multimedia_item.caption: The Braschler triplets were born in 1997. According to a new report from the National Center for Health Statistics, the rate of triplet and higher-order births dropped 41 percent from 1998 to 2014. More than 90 percent of these births are triplets.
multimedia_item.copyright: Nick Gonzales/The Grand Rapids Press, via Associated Press

multimedia_item.caption: The Braschler triplets were born in 1997. According to a new report from the National Center for Health Statistics, the rate of triplet and higher-order births dropped 41 percent from 1998 to 2014. More than 90 percent of these births are triplets.

news_item.title: South Sudan Struggles to Collect Taxes After Years of War
news_item.abstract: The world’s youngest country has, at least officially, emerged from civil war, but its government has done little to right a devastated economy.

multimedia_item.caption: Displaced people waiting this month in Wau, South Sudan, to register with aid organizations. The country has, at least officially, emerged from more than two years of civil war that killed tens of thousands of people and displaced over two million.
multimedia_item.copyright: Albert Gonzalez Farran/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
